user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
```c
bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /*
     * Check if the obj_id is both valid and matches
     * the specified creator_id
     */
    return (OS_ObjectIdIsValid(obj->active_id) && (OS_ObjectIdEqual(filter->creator_id, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) ||
                                                   OS_ObjectIdEqual(obj->creator, filter->creator_id)));
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function contains only an initialization and a single return statement whose result is formed from nested Boolean subexpressions using short-circuit operators. There is no code after the return, no conditional compilation, no labeled blocks or multiple branches that would introduce statically unreachable statements beyond the listed expression parts. Therefore only the assignment and the subexpressions making up the return expression need investigation for potential reachability issues (e.g. whether some subexpressions can never be evaluated due to short-circuiting or due to always-true/always-false conditions). All other parts of the snippet (comments, function header, braces) do not contain unreachable code and do not need further investigation.
